Dear Ms. Moffett:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
01/13/2022. An Exit Conference was held with the agency on 01/19/2022. Due to the
violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of
any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat non-
compliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
(i) The Michigan state police or the equivalent state or
Canadian provincial law enforcement agency where the person
usually resides.
(ii) An entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state or Canadian provincial law
enforcement agency where the person usually resides.
One of two new employee records reviewed did not show
documentation of a criminal record check for the employee
before her 3/29/2021 date of hire.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has
not been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the
person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
One of two new employee records reviewed did not show
documentation of a central registry clearance check for the
employee before her 3/29/2021 date of hire. Nor a central
registry record check in Florida where the employee had resided
as recent as 2021.
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(2) The foster parent/agency agreement shall contain all of the
following provisions:
(e) The role of the lawyer guardian ad litem and the court.
Four of four open foster home records reviewed, and two of two
closed foster home records reviewed did not show a foster
parent/agency agreement which showed documentation of (e).
4

The agency acknowledged its most recent foster parent/agency
agreement does not contain this requirement, as indicated by
the rule.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of four open foster home records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 The agency’s recommendation for the foster home’s
renewal was completed three days prior to the foster
home’s 11/20/2021 expiration date.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the
time of the change in placement and the needs that remain to
be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) and (b) as required by the rule.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 3 months before
being placed in foster care or a new physical examination shall
be completed within 30 calendar days after being placed in
foster care.
One of six open foster child records reviewed showed the
child’s physical exam due by 11/7/2021 was completed 12 days
late on 11/19/2021.
5

R400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not showed
compliance:
 The child’s MMR vaccine became overdue and was
complete after the requirement date on 1/5/2022.
 This record did not show documentation of the child’s
Polio vaccine which was overdue on 2/10/2021.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of 11 updated service plans reviewed was completed 13
days late.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MISACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
At the time of file review, various licensing, adoption, and foster
care records reviewed did not show consistent uploads of all
case related documents and or all applicable report signature
pages.
ISEP 6.30 Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66).
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload.
6

Two of six of open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of an April 2021
meeting.
 A second record did not show documentation of a June
2021 meeting.
ISEP 6.33 Assessments and Service Plans.
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
One of 15 service plans reviewed was not signed by the birth
parent.
ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, and
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors) and
provided to the foster care provider.
In one of six open foster child records reviewed, the record did
not show documentation of consistent quarterly medical
passports.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2020.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
7

-Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
-Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Of 11 updated service plans reviewed, one did not show
compliance:
 The FTM for the child’s 5/28/2021-8/25/2021 USP was
documented as completed on 6/29/2021, which was
sooner than what is required by the standard.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2020.
FOM 722-6H Documentation of contacts.
At minimum, the primary foster care caseworker assigned to the
case must complete case contacts according to the
requirements listed in this item.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed showed various
social work contacts of homes visits with the child and caregiver
which did not show consist documentation of a quality visit as
defined by the standard.
The contact was very brief and did not consistently indicate
whether there was an assessment of medical, physical and or
mental health needs related the child, discussion of the case
plan, or indication in the narrative of giving the child opportunity
to ask questions alone, if applicable.
FOM 722-8 Foster Care- Initial Service Plan.
Supervisory Approval:
Review and approve the ISP within 14 calendar days of the
Report Date.
One of four initial service plans reviewed was approved 4 days
late.
ADM 300 Child Adoption Assessment Addendum.
The DHS-606, Child Adoption Assessment Addendum, must be
used to update the DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, on
an annual basis if the child has not been placed for adoption.
In one of six adoption child records reviewed the record did not
show documentation of a child adoption addendum due by
1/6/2021 per the last one documented as 1/6/2020.
8

ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress reports.
Quarterly progress reports (DHHA-614) are to be completed
each quarter.
Two of six child adoption records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One did not show documentation of a quarterly due for
September and December of 2021.
 A second did not show documentation of a quarterly due
for November 2020 and January 2021.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Report.
 The agency is advised to show in the narrative section of the progress report
the home visit date(s) so as to clearly show that the face-to-face contact was
a home visit. Additionally, to indicate in the written narrative whether the child
was seen alone.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Nothing this inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
This corrective action plan related to the agency March 2021 Interim Inspection
where it received the following citations:
 R400.12324(1) for Reevaluation.
 R400.12418 (2)(a) & (b) for Updated service plans.
 Policy SMR 200 for Fingerprints.
With the exception of R400.12418(2)(b) where the agency received a repeat violation
this inspection, the agency remains in compliance with the corrective action plan.
9

DCWL ANALYST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
The Analyst’s inspection completion was still pending at the time of completion of the
agency’s renewal inspection. One safety alert was indicated:
Concern:
The 17-year-old foster child is sleeping in the basement and there isn’t means of
egress. The family lives in an apartment.
Solution:
The agency reports the caregiver and children reside in a townhouse not an apartment.
The home has two-bedrooms. This is the home the children resided in with their birth
parent prior to the agency’s involvement in the case. The birth parent moved out and
the maternal grandmother moved in with the children. During that earlier time, the 17-
year-old youth had slept in the basement by choice; reportedly for the privacy it offered.
This was all prior to the agency’s acceptance of the case on 5/5/2021. Currently and
since the agency’s acceptance of the case, the 17-year-old youth occupies one of the
two bedrooms in the home. The grandmother and the three younger children, ages,
one, two and three share the other bedroom. All the occupants have beds. As for
arrangement for the future, the 17-year-old youth will be 18 on 2/2/2022. He plans to
ask the court at the next hearing for permission to be removed from the case. He will
move from the home; he wants to return to the birth mother.
RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
